multiple-choice.question: What is the most reliable approach breeders have found to increase the captive population of pandas?

options.label: B
options.text: Showing young pandas footage of mating elders

options.label: C
options.text: Offering young pandas doses of Viagra

multiple-choice.question: Why are pandas' natural environments important for their reproduction?

options.label: A
options.text: They provide a safe space for pandas to mate

options.label: B
options.text: They allow pandas to engage in complex courtship behaviors

options.label: C
options.text: They give pandas the space they need to get down to business

title: The unbelievable science of how we read

multiple-choice.question: What is the secret about reading that Joe reveals at the beginning of the video?

options.label: A
options.text: Letters that appear to be the same size are actually the same size.

options.label: B
options.text: Letters that appear to be the same size are actually slightly different in height.

options.label: C
options.text: Reading is a skill that we have evolved to do.

options.label: D
options.text: Reading is a skill that we have not evolved to do.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the illusion that Joe demonstrates with two lines of different lengths?
According to Dr. Brozovsky, what is the "paradox of reading"?

options.label: A
options.text: Our brains are not able to read and recognize words.

options.label: B
options.text: Our brains are able to read and recognize words, despite reading being a relatively recent invention.

options.label: C
options.text: Our brains are able to read and recognize words, but only in certain languages.

options.label: D
options.text: Our brains are not able to read and recognize words, but only in certain contexts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of "neural recycling"?

options.label: A
options.text: Our brains reuse existing neural pathways to recognize patterns and shapes.

options.label: B
options.text: Our brains create new neural pathways to recognize patterns and shapes.

options.label: C
options.text: Our brains do not reuse existing neural pathways to recognize patterns and shapes.

options.label: D
options.text: Our brains reuse existing neural pathways to recognize patterns and shapes, but only in certain contexts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "shape alphabet" that our brains use to decode visual scenes?

options.label: A
options.text: A set of basic shapes that our brains use to recognize patterns and shapes.

options.label: B
options.text: A set of complex shapes that our brains use to recognize patterns and shapes.

options.label: C
options.text: A set of abstract shapes that our brains use to recognize patterns and shapes.

options.label: D
options.text: A set of shapes that our brains use to recognize patterns and shapes, but only in certain contexts.

multiple-choice.question: How do our eyes move when we read?

options.label: A
options.text: Our eyes move smoothly across the page.

options.label: B
options.text: Our eyes jump around the page, using a technique called "saccades."

options.label: C
options.text: Our eyes do not move when we read.

options.label: D
options.text: Our eyes move in a zig-zag pattern when we read.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of saccades when we read?

options.label: A
options.text: To gather information from different parts of our vision.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a coherent picture of the text.

options.label: C
options.text: To recognize patterns and shapes in the text.

options.label: D
options.text: To move our eyes smoothly across the page.

multiple-choice.question: How do our brains recognize words when we read?

options.label: A
options.text: By processing the shape of the word.

options.label: B
options.text: By processing the letters that make up the word.

options.label: C
options.text: By recognizing the pattern of the word.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a combination of the above methods.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "word superiority effect"?

options.label: A
options.text: The effect where our brains recognize words more easily than individual letters.

options.label: B
options.text: The effect where our brains recognize individual letters more easily than words.

options.label: C
options.text: The effect where our brains do not recognize words or individual letters.

options.label: D
options.text: The effect where our brains recognize words and individual letters equally.

multiple-choice.question: How quickly do our brains recognize words when we read?

options.label: B
options.text: In less than a quarter of a second.

title: Why is Texas hold 'em so popular? - James McManus

multiple-choice.question: Where did the game of poker first emerge?
What were the two games that ruled the card tables in New Orleans?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduced the popularity of the game

options.label: B
options.text: It had no impact on the game

options.label: B

options.text: Because it encouraged too much cheating

Where is the annual World Series of Poker held?

title: The science of laughter - Sasha Winkler

multiple-choice.question: What happens to our abdominal muscles when we laugh?
Why do scientists believe that laughter may have originated in our ancient ancestors?

options.label: A
options.text: As a way to signal aggressive intent.

options.label: B
options.text: As a way to signal friendly, non-aggressive intent.

options.label: C
options.text: As a way to communicate with other animals.

options.label: D
options.text: As a way to laugh at ourselves.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of simply hearing clips of laughter?

options.label: B
options.text: It can trigger a smile or laugh.

multiple-choice.question: Why is human laughter generally louder than that of other animals?

options.label: C
options.text: Because our laughter functions as a broadcast to everyone around.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between fake, or volitional, laughter and spontaneous laughter?

options.label: A
options.text: Fake laughter is produced in the same networks as spontaneous laughter.

options.label: B
options.text: Fake laughter is produced in entirely different networks in the brain, relying on speech-like pathways.

options.label: C
options.text: Fake laughter is produced in the brain's emotional centers.

options.label: D
options.text: Fake laughter is produced in the brain's rational centers.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of laughing?
Why is laughter thought to be good for us?

options.label: B
options.text: Because it releases feel-good neurotransmitters and decreases stress hormones.

multiple-choice.question: Who can reliably tell the difference between close friends and acquaintances based on their laughter?

options.label: C
options.text: Observers as young as 5 months old.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of people who laugh more?

options.label: C
options.text: They have the same cardiovascular health.

multiple-choice.question: Why is laughter a universal human behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is unique to humans.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a learned behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a natural behavior that is present in all humans.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a cultural behavior.

title: Does planting trees actually cool the planet? - Carolyn Beans

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the Chilean government's afforestation efforts between 1974 and 2012 resulted in no major carbon storage gains?

options.label: C
options.text: The use of non-native tree species

options.label: D
options.text: The failure to protect the land from wildfires

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between afforestation and reforestation?

options.label: A
options.text: Afforestation involves planting trees in areas with existing forests, while reforestation involves planting trees in areas without forests

options.label: B
options.text: Afforestation involves planting non-native tree species, while reforestation involves planting native tree species

options.label: C
options.text: Afforestation involves planting trees in areas devoid of forests, while reforestation involves restoring degraded forests

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It allows nature to regenerate and re-green the planet

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A method of harvesting trees in areas with existing forests

options.label: C
options.text: A method of helping nature along by removing grasses that compete with saplings, preventing grazing, and planting trees in small patches

options.label: D
options.text: A method of protecting existing forests from wildfires

multiple-choice.question: What is the main drawback of planting trees in areas that are not suitable for forests?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It can contribute to a warmer planet

options.label: C
options.text: It can lead to the destruction of existing forests

options.label: D
options.text: It can lead to the loss of carbon storage

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to the loss of biodiversity

options.label: B
options.text: It can contribute to a warmer planet

options.label: C
options.text: It can lead to the destruction of existing forests

options.label: D
options.text: It can lead to the failure of tree planting efforts to achieve their goals
